etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in James Napier (1810–1884), industrial chemist. From replate

definitions: An object or surface that is to be or has been replated. Also: a second or subsequent instance of plating, specifically from the same electrolytic solution.
A second or subsequent plating of a microbiological culture.
An act of replating a newspaper or other publication; a printed page or text resulting from this.

etymologies: late 18th century; earliest use found in William Felton (fl. c1794). From re- + plate

definitions: To renew the metal plating on (an object).
To make a new plate of (a page of type); to alter one or more of the plates of (a newspaper, book, etc.) to correct an error or add information before printing.
